title: Newark and Passaic Railway
text:
The Newark and Passaic Railway was incorporated on Nov 22, 1889 by the <a href="Lehigh%20Valley%20Railroad">Lehigh Valley Railroad</a> (LVRR). It was chartered as a short line in <a href="Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a> from the <a href="Passaic%20River">Passaic River</a> to a connection with the LVRR's <a href="Newark%20and%20Roselle%20Railway">Newark and Roselle Railway</a> near Pennsylvania Avenue in Newark. The lower mile of its length closed a gap in the route of the LVRR from <a href="South%20Plainfield%2C%20New%20Jersey">South Plainfield</a> to <a href="Jersey%20City%2C%20New%20Jersey">Jersey City</a>. 
In 1891 the LVRR consolidated the railroads along the Jersey City route into the <a href="Lehigh%20Valley%20Terminal%20Railway">Lehigh Valley Terminal Railway</a>. Along with the Newark and Passaic the other consolidated companies were the <a href="Roselle%20and%20South%20Plainfield%20Railway">Roselle and South Plainfield Railway</a>, the <a href="Newark%20and%20Roselle%20Railway">Newark and Roselle Railway</a>, the <a href="Newark%20Railway">Newark Railway</a>, the <a href="Jersey%20City%2C%20Newark%2C%20and%20Western%20Railway">Jersey City, Newark, and Western Railway</a>, the <a href="Jersey%20City%20Terminal%20Railway">Jersey City Terminal Railway</a>, and the <a href="Edgewater%20Railway">Edgewater Railway</a>.
After consolidation, the upper portion of the line served as the Newark and Passaic Branch of the LVRR, running from the west end of Oak Island yard to Hamburg Place.
